{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3645148,"name":"Abdullah Khaled","username":"Squirre1Master","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/squirre1master/{size}/266909_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-04T02:26:24.050Z","cooked":"

Hi CD! Our team (and likely many others) have historically struggled with tuning PID, often taking our programmers at least a day or more to dial in one subsystem. Even then, the outcome is not as efficient or smooth as other teams (1678 and 9483 come to mind). As such, I was wondering if there are any resources to help teams learn PID tuning not only conceptually, but pragmatically as well. Resources could include (but are not limited to):

  1. Media (i.e. books, videos, articles) explaining how PID and feedforward work from a mathematical/theoretical point of view
  2. Examples both simulated, like WPILib’s, or IRL walk-throughs of how teams tune their gains
  3. How to guesstimate good PID values given the information of a system (e.g. given the motor has x speed, y torque, and z load on it, what values would be good?).
  4. Links to other CD threads that have asked similar information to what is in this post
","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2025-06-04T02:26:47.307Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":22,"reads":361,"readers_count":360,"score":217.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":502784,"topic_slug":"pid-tuning-tips-tricks","display_username":"Abdullah Khaled","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://docs.wpilib.org/en/stable/docs/software/advanced-controls/introduction/index.html","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Advanced Controls Introduction — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation","clicks":6}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":72062,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/pid-tuning-tips-tricks/502784/1","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3645151,"name":"Tim Winters","username":"ArchdukeTim","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/archduketim/{size}/256125_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-04T02:30:54.000Z","cooked":"

A big factor is mechanical robustness. If your mechanism has a lot of slop or backlash, you’re gonna have a tough time tuning no matter what.

Ty has good info about this here:

Team 2056 OP Robotics Technical Binder Release Technical
There’s no positional feedforward for either the shoulder or the elbow. Both are the motion magic control modes from CTRE. (There is a kV value for the velocity feedforward built into motion magic) The elbow is small enough that you don’t need any elaborate control scheme to achieve the accuracy required for the application. The shoulder was counter balanced with a pair of gas springs that made the shoulder pivot weight neutral through its working range of motion. Gas springs also act as a dam…

You may want to pay attention to CD. I am going to announce a few useful tools that you may want to use in the future that will help with tuning, and development. We are working on completing them more before we open it up.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2025-06-04T02:35:38.334Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":313,"readers_count":312,"score":222.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":502784,"topic_slug":"pid-tuning-tips-tricks","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":10}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51887,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"YAGSL Creator & Maintainer"},"post_url":"/t/pid-tuning-tips-tricks/502784/3","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":9},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":10,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3645164,"name":"Sam Carlberg","username":"SamCarlberg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/samcarlberg/{size}/207684_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-04T02:37:30.481Z","cooked":"
Squirre1Master:

(e.g. given the motor has x speed, y torque, and z load on it, what values would be good?).

SysID does exactly this based on measurements taken of your system (but requires good data logging). You can also calculate PD values yourself if you have a very good model of the system’s motor intrinsics and mass/moment of inertia (usually derived from a detailed CAD model)

Seconding Tim that PIDF control cannot compensate for slop and backlash. You need to ensure that belts and chains are properly tensioned, and possibly shims on gears/sprockets/pulleys to remove slop between them and their axles.

Does nstrike have some super secret PID tuning automator in this works

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2025-06-04T02:59:42.625Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":262,"readers_count":261,"score":57.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":502784,"topic_slug":"pid-tuning-tips-tricks","display_username":"Carter Ryba","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":51887,"username":"nstrike","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nstrike/{size}/167038_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65624,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"9764, 10219"},"post_url":"/t/pid-tuning-tips-tricks/502784/5","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3645267,"name":"","username":"LHACK4142","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/lhack4142/{size}/196107_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-04T04:33:39.716Z","cooked":"

Not sure what could be taking an entire day to tune a subsystem, but if it helps, my general procedure is:

  1. start with a comically small P (like 0.00001)
  2. Increase by orders of magnitude till you see any movement at all
  3. use your judgement to increase P until it slightly overshoots (by use your judgement, I mean don’t increase by orders of magnitude probably, and just be somewhat conservative)
  4. Decrease P till it doesn’t overshoot/you get the desired results.
  5. Ignore I and D

To be clear, this is for straight PID control, not motion profiles. It should only take like a maximum of 12 deploys to tune, which is not that long given that you’re only changing one number per deploy. Unless compilation takes really long, idk because my team uses Python. If you don’t trust me, I think there’s at least one powerhouse team that uses this approach.
Remember that kP, kI, kD have units. If you’ve told your sparkmax that it’s in radians, then kP’s units are (duty cycle) / (radian).

In terms of media explaining PID, I liked this video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wkfEZmsQqiA&ab_channel=MATLAB
For feedforwards, I liked this article: Introduction to DC Motor Feedforward — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation
PIDF took a long period of marination in my mind to understand it fully so your programmers may need some time as well. That said, the above instructions work well enough that they’re probably usable before the concepts have marinated fully.

For examples, I say just try it yourself with the above instructions.

In terms of guesstimation, don’t do it. It doesn’t really help, and is not as easy/helpful as the above instructions.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2025-06-04T04:44:38.292Z","reply_count":3,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":242,"readers_count":241,"score":98.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":502784,"topic_slug":"pid-tuning-tips-tricks","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://docs.wpilib.org/en/stable/docs/software/advanced-controls/introduction/introduction-to-feedforward.html#introduction-to-dc-motor-feedforward","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Introduction to DC Motor Feedforward — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation","clicks":8},{"url":"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wkfEZmsQqiA&ab_channel=MATLAB","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":6}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":58301,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"coder in the corner"},"post_url":"/t/pid-tuning-tips-tricks/502784/6","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3645277,"name":"Tim Winters","username":"ArchdukeTim","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/archduketim/{size}/256125_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-04T04:50:34.430Z","cooked":"

D is still useful in FRC.

I like to start with a P value that will give full motor output for ~1/2 the range of travel, and then increase as needed. For example, suppose you’re tuning an elevator that has a travel distance of 48 inches. Half of that is 24, so you want to solve for kP in 12 = kP * 24. So I’d start with a kP of .5, assuming the error units is inches. If it was meters, then the equation becomes 12 = kP * .6, so kP would instead be 20.

Nowadays it’s recommended to use rotations of the output stage as the measurement value, but the concept still applies. For something like an arm that has 180º of motion (or .5 rotations), solve 12 = kP * .25 (since .25 rotations is half of the full range of travel). So kP would be 48 here.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2025-06-04T04:50:34.430Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":208,"readers_count":207,"score":121.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":502784,"topic_slug":"pid-tuning-tips-tricks","display_username":"Tim Winters","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":58301,"username":"LHACK4142","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/lhack4142/{size}/196107_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":19820,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"78 AIR Strike Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/pid-tuning-tips-tricks/502784/7","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3645278,"name":"","username":"LHACK4142","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/lhack4142/{size}/196107_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-04T04:55:38.211Z","cooked":"
ArchdukeTim:

D is still useful in FRC.

Personally I haven’t noticed much difference from using D – in my experience it’s kinda a diminishing returns thing – but I know 2659 uses it, and they do seem to have great, snappy controls.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2025-06-04T04:55:38.211Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":199,"readers_count":198,"score":39.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":502784,"topic_slug":"pid-tuning-tips-tricks","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":58301,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"coder in the corner"},"post_url":"/t/pid-tuning-tips-tricks/502784/8","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3645283,"name":"Kabir","username":"kn4","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kn4/{size}/235296_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-04T05:31:58.594Z","cooked":"

In my opinion, needing a deploy for tuning results in a lot of lost time (although I haven’t worked with robotpy before so I don’t know how fast deploys are with it). If you’re tuning PID controllers running on a motor controller, it’s usually faster to use that vendor’s configuration app to change the PID values. Otherwise you can try reading values from a dashboard.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2025-06-04T05:32:21.237Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":193,"readers_count":192,"score":113.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":502784,"topic_slug":"pid-tuning-tips-tricks","display_username":"Kabir","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":58301,"username":"LHACK4142","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/lhack4142/{size}/196107_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57470,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2724 programmer"},"post_url":"/t/pid-tuning-tips-tricks/502784/9","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3645305,"name":"","username":"pigrammer","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/pigrammer/{size}/234083_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-04T09:21:49.673Z","cooked":"

You don’t need to deploy every time if you use WPILib’s PIDController, you can publish it to NetworkTables and edit the gains from your dashboard; just make sure to put them in the code any time you do re deploy while doing this.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2025-06-04T09:21:49.673Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":177,"readers_count":176,"score":95.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":502784,"topic_slug":"pid-tuning-tips-tricks","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":58301,"username":"LHACK4142","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/lhack4142/{size}/196107_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":64857,"hidden":false,"trust_level":3,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"246 Software Lead"},"post_url":"/t/pid-tuning-tips-tricks/502784/10","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3645306,"name":"Jimmy McCosker","username":"Jimmyy","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jimmyy/{size}/199505_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-04T09:32:49.115Z","cooked":"

This season, we followed a guide in the post linked below from team 3255 to tune our elevator, and it worked out pretty well.

FRC 3255 SuperNURDs - 2025 Build Thread FRC Open Alliance
Sorry for the late response; I was locked in writing for the BEACH BLITZ SCHOLARSHIP!!! We tune our subsystems in an unorthodox way, but its the way that we’ve seen work! I highly recommend using Phoenix Tuner to do this, as it’s been the fastest way for us to change motor constants. Feedforward Set all PID constants to 0 Command the elevator to go to a non-zero position Raise your elevator up by hand to that position (or higher), and…
","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2025-06-04T09:33:00.601Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":176,"readers_count":175,"score":50.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":502784,"topic_slug":"pid-tuning-tips-tricks","display_username":"Jimmy McCosker","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/frc-3255-supernurds-2025-build-thread/477499/116","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"FRC 3255 SuperNURDs - 2025 Build Thread","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":52943,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"9496AM | Programming, Electrical, Strategy"},"post_url":"/t/pid-tuning-tips-tricks/502784/11","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3645395,"name":"Jeffrey Davis","username":"Practicality","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/practicality/{size}/208492_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-04T13:53:55.828Z","cooked":"

So, a practical tip is to use recalc or something similar when initially building the system, so that 100% output will be the fastest you’ll ever want to go on that part. https://www.reca.lc/. That will give you useful powers across the board and help with other things too.

Then you can skip the comically low p value and start at .01 (1%). That’s usually pretty close to the power that moves the system but really slowly. You can still be more careful and go slower if you want. Regardless, having the right gear ratios for the speed and power you want will dramatically ease the task of tuning pid values.

Our process for tuning our elevator this year was essentially what is described in the Motion Profiled, Feedforward, and Feedback Control section implemented using WPILib classes:

FIRST Robotics Competition Documentation

Tuning a Vertical Elevator with Motion Profiling

In this section, we will tune a simple position controller for a vertical elevator. In addition, we will discuss the advantages of using motion profiling for this situation. About the Profiler: A M...

To find feedforward gains, we followed that process with one minor change to step 3. To find kS (voltage needed to overcome static friction), which was omitted for simplicity there, we did the following:

Find the minimum voltage at which the elevator starts moving up. This gives kG + kS
Find the maximum voltage at which the elevator moves downwards. This is kG - kS
Solve the system of equations to find kG and kS

It worked pretty well for us, visualizing data using AdvantageScope. I would definitely use pigrammer’s suggestion to avoid redeploying every time. I have heard good things about DogLog so I would check out their tunable system, though I haven’t personally used it.

There are definitely some things cooking in the FRC open source community this offseason

Curious as to what some of those might be?

If you want practice writing & tuning PID loops from scratch*, I like this simulator. It’s not made for FRC and uses javascript, but it gamifies the process in a way with increasing levels of difficulty.

*If you don't want to write one from scratch

This will only work for levels with blocks and distance but you get the idea

var p_val;
var i_val = 0;
var prev_p = 0;
var d_val;

/*you change these*/
var kP = 1;
var kI = 0;
var kD = 0;

function controlFunction(block)
{
 /*error: distance from setpoint, in this case the setpoint is 0*/
  p_val = 0-block.x

/*accumulated error*/
  i_val += block.x  

/*change in error*/
  d_val = p_val - prev_p; 
  
  return kP*p_val + kI*i_val + kD * d_val;
  
}

Something like this website can be helpful to practice tuning the PID constants but isn’t terribly intuitive.

The only one that’s mine to announce is a LQR plugin for ReCalc that does the same thing as SysId Theoretical Mode. So, ReCalc will be able to give you optimal P and D gains for your mechanism(*).

(*) if you specify all the parameters correctly…

There’s active discussion of all this stuff on the FRC discord, for what it’s worth.

","post_number":18,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2025-06-04T22:52:39.384Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":17,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":81,"readers_count":80,"score":86.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":502784,"topic_slug":"pid-tuning-tips-tricks","display_username":"Tyler Veness","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":16846,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"WPILib controls | Choreo optimizer backend"},"post_url":"/t/pid-tuning-tips-tricks/502784/18","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3646087,"name":"Dan","username":"tekdemo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tekdemo/{size}/138330_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-04T23:01:17.332Z","cooked":"

Slightly tangent to your problem, but I would also make sure you’re accounting for feed-forwards and motion profiling. A bit of understanding here will give you much better results for much lower time investment than deep dives into PIDs will. The PID math is intended for a specific problem set, and it’s easy to utilize it in a way where the math performs sub-optimally.

We too used to spend hours on pid tuning just to get adequate control, and that changed significantly once we figured this out. This year the amount of PID tuning on systems was nearly zero; We just guessed a P value, roughly dialed feed-forwards do the heavy lifting, set achievable motion profile constraints, and had sharp, precise motions. It’s really surprising how little you need to care about the PID loop when the feed forwards and motion profile are involved, since they keep the system error very stable, and near zero at all times.
As the season went on we only ever had to slightly tweak the feed-forwards to better model the system, but never had to really mess with our lone P term on feedback.

It’s a much more fulfilling process, imo.
